<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FINANCE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/us-banks-crush-earnings-and-signal-more-good-times-ahead?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Banks Make Bank
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/us-banks-crush-earnings-and-signal-more-good-times-ahead?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Wall Street sign in gold " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/5e56e4f176e8d62e3afe0fd70da0f30e8986bc92-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba </em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The country’s six largest banks—JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley, Citigroup, Wells Fargo, Bank of America, and Goldman Sachs—all reported their earnings for the summer quarter this week. As Larry David would say, the results were prettay, prettay good.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Just three quarters through 2021, Goldman Sachs has already notched its <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-15/goldman-traders-deliver-surprise-surge-in-firm-s-best-year-ever?srnd=premium" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">best year ever</a> in terms of revenue. The hero last quarter was its investment banking unit, which rode a dealmaking spree to an 88% sales bump.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What else did we learn from banks?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Covid didn’t wreck the economy as feared. </strong>In those unprecedented days last spring, banks stashed away money in a rainy day fund to prepare for a wave of loan defaults—but those never came. JPMorgan said this week it was <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/10/13/business/news-business-stock-market/jpmorgans-profit-surges-as-its-deal-makers-cash-in-on-mergers?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">releasing $2.1 billion</a> from the cash pile under its mattress.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Spending is up. </strong>Wells Fargo said that debit card spending was higher <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/10/15/investing/premarket-stocks-trading/index.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">every single week</a> last quarter when compared to 2019. And at Citi, credit card spending is “well above 2019 levels.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The trading boom is mostly going strong. </strong>Concerts and socializing are back, but many people are still trading stocks as if we were in lockdown: Bank of America, Morgan Stanley, and Goldman all reported higher sales from trading last quarter. In all, five US banks made an additional <a href="https://www.reuters.com/business/wall-street-banks-set-profit-again-when-fed-withdraws-pandemic-stimulus-2021-10-15/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$51 billion in trading revenue</a> over the last seven quarters compared to the same period pre-Covid.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">CEOs see inflation sticking around: </strong>Most bank executives agreed that inflation wasn’t as transitory as once predicted, and Morgan Stanley CEO James Gorman went so far as to <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-14/-prick-this-bubble-morgan-stanley-ceo-calls-for-fed-rate-hikes?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">urge the Fed</a> to hike rates by Q1 of next year, months before the Fed has planned on it. “You’ve got to prick this bubble a little bit,” Gorman said.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">But the best times could be ahead</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As the Fed prepares to wind down the stimulus measures that supported markets, investors will need to reshuffle their portfolios to adapt—potentially leading to even more $$$ for banks. And their skyrocketing share prices reflect that optimism: The KBW Bank index has doubled the S&P 500 this year, and Goldman is the Dow’s top stock, up 51% since Jan. 1.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TRAVEL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/the-us-reverses-historic-restrictions-on-international-travelers?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
International Terminal, Ghost Town No More
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Starting Nov. 8, vaccinated international travelers will <a href="https://www.axios.com/us-restrictions-fully-vaccinated-foreign-travelers-bb49a3e8-7fcb-41a4-8c08-fe26e4a0e2b9.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">be allowed</a> to enter the US by air—meaning families can reunite for the holidays and ask you in-person why you don’t have kids yet. Nonessential land border travel from Mexico and Canada will also reopen next month.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Together the twin announcements, both issued by the White House this week, reverse historic restrictions that barred most foreigners, including those from the EU, the UK, and China, from entering the US for the last 21 months—if time still means anything to you.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Everyone, US citizens and noncitizens alike, will still have to present a negative Covid-19 test taken within three days of arrival.</span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Following the news yesterday afternoon, hotel and airline stocks ticked up.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>The travel industry <a href="https://www.reuters.com/world/us/exclusive-us-partly-lift-international-travel-curbs-nov-8-official-2021-10-15/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">really needs</a> this tourism boost. The US Transportation Department released new stats Friday revealing that international air traffic was down 43% in August and 21% overall compared to before the pandemic.—<em>JW</em></p>
</div>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CRYPTO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/bitcoin-could-finally-get-it-s-very-own-etf?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Bitcoin Follows Fall Out Boy’s Lead
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/bitcoin-could-finally-get-it-s-very-own-etf?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="bitcoin bull" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/173c37c9b5b40bfdd41ea9aefff2456eddf96b30-846x562.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s going mainstream. The world’s largest cryptocurrency topped $60,000 yesterday in anticipation of the SEC’s reported decision to <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/15/the-sec-is-poised-to-allow-the-first-bitcoin-futures-etfs.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">approve</a> the first bitcoin futures ETFs next week.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">ETF?</strong> An exchange-traded fund is a security that tracks anything from a collection of stocks to a group of commodities—a securities soup, if you will. You can buy an ETF as you would a regular stock.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Crypto traders have been bugging the SEC to approve a bitcoin-based ETF since 2013, but regulators have pushed back, citing the coin’s volatility and the crypto industry’s lack of transparency. So getting these ETFs approved—there are four that could begin trading this month—would be a win for those trying to put crypto in front of institutional investors.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Important note:</strong> These ETFs aren’t<em> bitcoin</em> ETFs—they’re bitcoin <em>futures</em> ETFs. That means investors in these ETFs won’t actually own any bitcoin, and instead will be buying futures contracts that allow them to bet on the direction of bitcoin’s price. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Bitcoin has gained almost 90% in the past three months and is close enough to taste its all-time high of $64,869.—<em>MM</em></p>
</div>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/key-performance-indicators-october-17?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators
</font></a>
</h1>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/key-performance-indicators-october-17?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Elon Musk dancing on SNL" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/aabe1de647dce383a01af96ace2fb3bc218611c4-480x267.gif?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>With a <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/15/elon-musk-is-worth-as-much-as-bill-gates-and-warren-buffett-combined.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">net worth</a> of $230 billion, Elon Musk is now about as wealthy as Bill Gates and Warren Buffett combined, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“Hey Ted Sarandos! Just a quick note to let you know that I would prefer if you didn’t drag my name into your mess.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Australian comedian Hannah Gadsby <a href="https://deadline.com/2021/10/hannah-gadsby-slams-netflix-ted-sarandos-dave-chappelle-defense-1234856317/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ripped into</a> Netflix Co-CEO Ted Sarandos in an Instagram post for including her name in his defense of airing Dave Chappelle’s standup special, <em>The Closer</em>, which has been criticized for Chappelle’s anti-trans comments. And the controversy keeps boiling: Netflix <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2021/10/15/22728337/netflix-fires-organizer-trans-employee-walkout-dave-chappelle?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">fired</a> the organizer of an upcoming Oct. 20 walkout for allegedly leaking internal metrics to the press.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>Small business owners have mixed emotions about Biden’s vaccine mandate. (<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/15/vaccine-mandate-small-business-owners-mixed-emotions?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Morning Brew</a>)<br></p>

style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe country’s six largest banks—JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley, Citigroup, Wells Fargo, Bank of America, and Goldman Sachs—all reported their earnings for the summer quarter this week. As Larry David would say, the results were prettay, prettay good.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eJust three quarters through 2021, Goldman Sachs has already notched its \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-15/goldman-traders-deliver-surprise-surge-in-firm-s-best-year-ever?srnd=premium\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebest year ever\u003c/a\u003e in terms of revenue. The hero last quarter was its investment banking unit, which rode a dealmaking spree to an 88% sales bump.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat else did we learn from banks?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eCovid didn’t wreck the economy as feared. \u003c/strong\u003eIn those unprecedented days last spring, banks stashed away money in a rainy day fund to prepare for a wave of loan defaults—but those never came. JPMorgan said this week it was \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/10/13/business/news-business-stock-market/jpmorgans-profit-surges-as-its-deal-makers-cash-in-on-mergers?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereleasing $2.1 billion\u003c/a\u003e from the cash pile under its mattress.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSpending is up. \u003c/strong\u003eWells Fargo said that debit card spending was higher \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/10/15/investing/premarket-stocks-trading/index.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eevery single week\u003c/a\u003e last quarter when compared to 2019. And at Citi, credit card spending is “well above 2019 levels.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe trading boom is mostly going strong. \u003c/strong\u003eConcerts and socializing are back, but many people are still trading stocks as if we were in lockdown: Bank of America, Morgan Stanley, and Goldman all reported higher sales from trading last quarter. In all, five US banks made an additional \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/business/wall-street-banks-set-profit-again-when-fed-withdraws-pandemic-stimulus-2021-10-15/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e$51 billion in trading revenue\u003c/a\u003e over the last seven quarters compared to the same period pre-Covid.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eCEOs see inflation sticking around: \u003c/strong\u003eMost bank executives agreed that inflation wasn’t as transitory as once predicted, and Morgan Stanley CEO James Gorman went so far as to \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-14/-prick-this-bubble-morgan-stanley-ceo-calls-for-fed-rate-hikes?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eurge the Fed\u003c/a\u003e to hike rates by Q1 of next year, months before the Fed has planned on it. “You’ve got to prick this bubble a little bit,” Gorman said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBut the best times could be ahead\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs the Fed prepares to wind down the stimulus measures that supported markets, investors will need to reshuffle their portfolios to adapt—potentially leading to even more $$$ for banks. And their skyrocketing share prices reflect that optimism: The KBW Bank index has doubled the S\u0026P 500 this year, and Goldman is the Dow’s top stock, up 51% since Jan. 1.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" href=\"https://www.axios.com/us-restrictions-fully-vaccinated-foreign-travelers-bb49a3e8-7fcb-41a4-8c08-fe26e4a0e2b9.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebe allowed\u003c/a\u003e to enter the US by air—meaning families can reunite for the holidays and ask you in-person why you don’t have kids yet. Nonessential land border travel from Mexico and Canada will also reopen next month.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTogether the twin announcements, both issued by the White House this week, reverse historic restrictions that barred most foreigners, including those from the EU, the UK, and China, from entering the US for the last 21 months—if time still means anything to you.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eEveryone, US citizens and noncitizens alike, will still have to present a negative Covid-19 test taken within three days of arrival.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFollowing the news yesterday afternoon, hotel and airline stocks ticked up.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThe travel industry \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/us/exclusive-us-partly-lift-international-travel-curbs-nov-8-official-2021-10-15/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereally needs\u003c/a\u003e this tourism boost. collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s going mainstream. The world’s largest cryptocurrency topped $60,000 yesterday in anticipation of the SEC’s reported decision to \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/15/the-sec-is-poised-to-allow-the-first-bitcoin-futures-etfs.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eapprove\u003c/a\u003e the first bitcoin futures ETFs next week.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eETF?\u003c/strong\u003e An exchange-traded fund is a security that tracks anything from a collection of stocks to a group of commodities—a securities soup, if you will. You can buy an ETF as you would a regular stock.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCrypto traders have been bugging the SEC to approve a bitcoin-based ETF since 2013, but regulators have pushed back, citing the coin’s volatility and the crypto industry’s lack of transparency. So getting these ETFs approved—there are four that could begin trading this month—would be a win for those trying to put crypto in front of institutional investors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eImportant note:\u003c/strong\u003e These ETFs aren’t\u003cem\u003e bitcoin\u003c/em\u003e ETFs—they’re bitcoin \u003cem\u003efutures\u003c/em\u003e ETFs. That means investors in these ETFs won’t actually own any bitcoin, and instead will be buying futures contracts that allow them to bet on the direction of bitcoin’s price. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eBitcoin has gained almost 90% in the past three months and is close
